title: Mum finds out about son's death through Facebook - In Other Media | The Star Online
text:
Monday, 13 February 2017 | MYT 12:23 PM Mum finds out about son's death through Facebook 
> Mum finds out about son's death through Facebook A 56-year-old woman reportedly found out about her son's death through Facebook after reading condolence messages written by friends on his page. Normadiah Ahmad, the mother of Muhammad Syahidin Zainudin, said she trembled upon reading the messages at 9am on Sunday morning. The 27-year-old had died less than an hour ago earlier in a car accident involving a trailer and two motorcycles along Jalan Gadong-LBJ in Nilai, Seremban. "I quickly called one of those who left a message to verify the news. The friend said my son was involved in an accident and had passed away," said Normadiah at Hospital Tuanku Ja'afar. According to Nilai OCPD Supt Zaidino Zaludin, the driver of the trailer lost control of his vehicle and veered into the opposite lane before crashing into Muhammad Syahidin and another motorcycle. Muhammad Syahidin was dragged 30m by the trailer and died at the scene. The rider and pillion rider of the other motorcycle and the trailer driver sustained serious injuries. 
> Actor Melvin Sia denies he has become very demanding Taiwan-based Malaysian actor Melvin Sia denies that he has become very demanding since achieving fame in Taiwan. Sia claimed instead that some people might have misunderstood him. "I am not a perfect person," he said. Sia reportedly recently demanded that a hair stylist only attend to him. He has also been reported to have lashed out at the crew on the set of his drama series. In 2015, Sia, who is from Sarawak, received a Best Supporting Actor nomination at the Taiwan Golden Bell Awards for his role in the drama The Way We Were. The Golden Bell Awards is Taiwan's equivalent of the Emmy Awards. 
> Actress Xiong rumoured to be pregnant Hong Kong-based actress and model Lynn Xiong is reported to be pregnant. The 36-year-old artiste was spotted going to a Chinese medicine clinic, which is popular among pregnant women, in Hong Kong with her husband Ken Kwok. Xiong, who was married in October last year, could not be contacted for comment at press time. Related Stories
